titleStmt.title: Iniunctions with certaine articles to be enquired of in the visitation of the Reuerend Father in Christ, Iohn, by Gods prouidence, Byshop of Norvvich, aswell to the clargie, as to the Churchwardens and quest men of euery seuerall parish within the dioces of Norvvich, [and] to be put in execution, by al the Archdeacons commissaries [and] other officers exercisinge ecclesiasticall iurisdiction, vnder the sayd Bishop in their synodes, visitation, and courtes. In the yeare of our Lord God. 1569.
Visitation articles. 1569

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Iniunctions with certaine Articles to be enquired of, in the Vi≈øitation of the Reuerend Father in Chri≈øt, Iohn, by Gods prouidence, By≈øhop of Norvvich, a≈øwell to the Clargie, as to the Churchwardens and que≈øt men of euery ≈øeuerall pari≈øh within the dioces of Norvvich, & to be put in execution, by al the Archdeacons Commi≈ø≈øaries & other officers exerci≈øinge eccle≈øia≈øticall iuri≈ødiction, under the ≈øayd Bi≈øhop in their Synodes, Vi≈øitation, and Courtes.
¬∂ In the yeare of our Lord God. 1569.

p.hi: Imprinted at London by Iohn VValley. Aprilis. 15.

div.head: Iniunctions. ¬∂ INIVNCTIONS VVITH CERtayne Articles to be enquired of, in the Vi≈øitation of the Reuerend father in Chri≈øt, Iohn, by gods prouidence, Bishop of Norvvich. &c.
¬∂ For the Clargie.
div.p: IN primis, you mu≈øt endeuour ≈øo to order & frame your ≈øelues in the ≈øetting foorth of Gods true Religion, due admini≈øtration of the Sacraments, and the reuerent and di≈øtincte ≈øaying or ≈øinging of the Common prayer, as hath bene pre≈øcribed and ≈øette forthe vnto you beefore tyme, a≈øwell by the booke of Common prayer ≈øet forth to be v≈øed through ye whole Realme, as by ≈øondry Iniunctions ≈øet foorth for that purpo≈øe. And that you take great heede, that your lyues and conuer≈øations be ≈øuch euery way, as no per≈øon haue cau≈øe to be offended thereby, ≈øomuch as in you lieth.

Item, ye ≈øhall not take vppon you to Preach, or Expounde the Scriptures by way of exhortation or otherwi≈øe, in your owne Church or el≈øe where, vnle≈ø≈øe you bee admitted thereto by the mo≈øte Reuerend Father, the Archby≈øhop of Canterbury, or the Bi≈øhop of the Dioces.

Item, you ≈øhall not marie or ≈øuffer to be maried within any of your cures, any per≈øonne or per≈øons,
that come lately out of any other Dioces, vnle≈ø≈øe ≈øuche per≈øons bring with them ≈øufficient te≈øtimoniall vnder the Seale of the Ordinarie of the Dioces from whence he or they ≈øhal come, te≈øtifying ≈øuch per≈øon or per≈øons to be free and vnmaryed, and at their liberty to mary accordingly.

Item, at ≈øuch tymes as ye ≈øhall v≈øe the perambulation in the Rogation dayes for the boundes of your pari≈øh, you ≈øhall not v≈øe any ≈øurples vppon you, or ≈øtay at any cro≈ø≈øe, or ≈øuffer any banners, to be caried, or other ≈øuper≈øtition to be v≈øed, but onely geue GOD thanks, and v≈øe ≈øuch good order of prayers and Homelies, as be appointed by the Queenes maie≈øties authoritie in that behalfe.
Item none of you ≈øhall ferme one cure or more within this Dioces, without ≈øpeciall lycence in wryting vnder the Bi≈øhops Seale.

Finally, ye ≈øhall diligently ob≈øerue and put in vre, all ≈øuch Orders & IniunctioÃÑs as haue ben appointed you before tyme, a≈øwell by the Iniunctions of the queenes maie≈øtie, as by ye Archbi≈øhop of Canterburyes grace, and the Bi≈øhop of the Dyoces.

div.head: ¬∂ For the Churchvvardens, Que≈øtmen and others.
div.p:
Item, that no Par≈øon Vicar, propriatorie, or fermer of any benefice, doe admit any Mini≈øter or
Curate to ≈øerue his ≈øaid benefice, vnle≈ø≈øe ≈øuch per≈øon ≈øhall fir≈øt ≈øhow his letters of Orders, where he was made Myni≈øter, and haue al≈øo ≈øufficient te≈øtimoniall vnder the Seale of the Ordinarye, from whence he commeth, with lycence from the Bi≈øhop to ≈øerue accordingly.

Item, that in great Churches where all the people cannot conuenieÃÑtly heare their mini≈øter, ye Church wardens & other, to whome that charge belongeth, ≈øhal prouide and appoint, a decent and a coÃÑuenient ≈øeate in the body of the church, where the ≈øayd mini≈øter may ≈øit or ≈øtand, and ≈øay the diuine ≈øeruice, that all the congregation may heare and be edified therewith. And that in ≈ømaller churches, ther be ≈øome conuenient ≈øeate without the chauncell dore for that purpo≈øe.

Item, that vppon all ≈øainctes daye and other like times, ther be no ringing of belles after Euening prayer, or any other ≈øuper≈øtitious ceremony v≈øed, to the maintenaunce of poperie, or praying for the dead, & that if any ≈øuch ≈øhalbe hence forth v≈øed, the ≈øame with the names of ≈øuche as ≈øhall offende therein, to bee pre≈øented to the Ordinary.

Item, that no per≈øon or per≈øons calling them ≈øelues lordes of mi≈ørule in the Chri≈øtmas tyme, or other vnreuerent per≈øons at any other tyme, pre≈øume to come into ye church vnreuereÃÑtly playing their lewd partes, we ≈øcoffing, ie≈øting, or rebaldry talke, & if any ≈øuch haue alredy offeÃÑded herein,
to pre≈øent them and their names to the Ordinary.

Item, for auoydinge of vnlawfull mariages, you ≈øhall prouide in euery of your Churches, a certayne table for the degrees of Mariage la≈øt ≈øet forth by the fore≈øayde mo≈øt Reuerend Father in God Mathevv, Archbi≈øhop of Canterbury, to be ≈øette vp in ≈øome conuenient place of the ≈øayd Church.

Finally, you ≈øhall carefully and diligently prouide, that all ≈øuch good Orders & Iniunctions, as haue ben pre≈øcribed & appointed beefore time, ≈øhalbe duly by you put in execution, ≈øo far forthe, as they concerne any of you.

IN primis, whether your Diuine ≈øeruice be ≈øayde or ≈øong in due tyme and reuerently, and the Sacraments duely and reuereÃÑtly myni≈øtred in ≈øuch decent apparel, as is appoynted by the laws, the Queenes maie≈øties Iniunctions, and other orders ≈øet forthe by publike aucthoritie in that behalfe.

Item, whether the Queenes maie≈øties Iniunctions, be quarterly read in your Churches, & a declaration read twy≈øe euery yeare, which was ≈øet forth by bothe the Archbi≈øhops and the re≈øte of the By≈øhops, concerning certayne principall pointes of Religion, for the vnitie of Doctrine.

Item, whether you haue in your Churche a
Bible, of the large≈øt volume, the Paraphra≈øis, of Era≈ømus in Engli≈øh, with the Homelies, & all other boks requi≈øite, for the Admini≈øtration of Diuine ≈øeruice. And whether the Homelies be duely and di≈øtinctly read.

Item, whether you haue in your Church a decent Pulpit and Communion table furni≈øhed and placed as becommeth, with a comly communion cup, with a couer, and a che≈øt or poore mans boxe, and the collection and di≈øtribution, for the poore, made according to a ≈øtatute in that behalfe prouided:

Item, whether any per≈øon or per≈øons haue pulled downe, any Church, Chappell, or Chauncell, almes hou≈øe, or belles, or any part thereof, or haue felled or ≈øpoyled any wood or tymber in any Church yarde, or haue ≈øolde any church goodes: to whome, what it was, and for what price.
Item, whether your Church, Chauncel, and your Par≈øonage and Vicaredge hou≈øe, be well & ≈øufficiently repaired and maintained, & whether that your Church yard be well kept and fenced,

Item, whether your Rodeloftes, Images, Tabernacles, and all other monuments of Idolatrie be pulled downe and defaced, and youre Church and Chauncell decently reformed. And whether you know of any Popi≈øh and ≈øuper≈øtitious bookes, Images, ve≈øtments, or ≈øuch lyke, remaining within your pari≈øh and in who≈øe hands they bee.

Item, whether your Preachers & Mini≈øters doe erne≈øtly and diligently teache theyr Auditory and pari≈øhiners, to lyue in faythfull and humble obedience to almighty GOD, the Queenes maie≈øtie, and all and ≈øinguler hir officers, a≈øwell ≈øpiritual as temporal, exhorting them from all kind of Idolatrie, ≈øuper≈øtition, and other vices.

Item whether your Mini≈øter be geuen to filthy lucre, whordome, dronkenne≈ø≈øe, or other like notorious vices, or doe haunt or frequent any ≈øu≈øpitious hou≈øe or company, or any vaine pa≈øtimes as hawking, hunting, di≈øing, carding, and ≈øuche like vanities, and geue not him ≈øelfe to prayer, fa≈øting, almes dedes, with ≈øuch like. And whether he pray diligently for the pro≈øperous e≈øtate of the Queenes maie≈øtie, as to duety belongeth.

Item, whether your Myni≈øter doe eudeuour him ≈øelfe diligently to teach & in≈øtruct the youth of the pari≈øh, the Catechi≈øme, and do otherwi≈øe ≈øee them brought vp in the feare of God, and in due obedience and reuerence, to their parentes, may≈øters and elders.

Item, whether your curate or Mini≈øter haue admitted any to Preache within your pari≈øhe church not being lawfully lycen≈øed thereunto, or haue refu≈øed any ≈øuche as are licen≈øed, and whether you haue your quarter ≈øermons.

Item, whether you know of any ≈øectaries, ye v≈øe to make any priuate conuenticles in priuate mens hou≈øes, in contempt of the lawes and good
orders ≈øet forthe by authoritie, and doe preache, teach, or mini≈øter the Sacraments there, and by that meanes attempt to withdrawe the people from due obedience, and to rai≈øe and maintaine ≈øci≈ømes & ≈øectes, who they are that ≈øo doe, where they do it, and what be the articles and contents of their doctrine and opinions.

Item, whether there be any Mini≈øter, Prie≈øt, or other per≈øone or per≈øons what≈øoeuer within your pari≈øh, that doeth willingly, ≈øinbburnely, or negligently, ab≈øent him ≈øelfe from the church and receuinge of the Sacramentes, and do refu≈øe to contribute to the poore mens box, and that walk vp and downe iangling and talking in the tyme of Common praier, or admini≈øtration of the Sacraments, any that v≈øe any other booke of prayers then is ≈øet forth by publike authoritie, or that haue not communicated thri≈øe euery yeare at the lea≈øt, nor ≈øubmit him ≈øelfe to the laws and orders ≈øet forth by common authoritie, and where ≈øuche per≈øon or per≈øons doe remaine, and who they are that doe maintaine them.
Item whether your Vicar or Par≈øon be re≈øident and kepeth ho≈øpitalitie in and vppon hys benefice, & howe many benefices he hath, expre≈ø≈øing their names.

Item, who is patroue of your benefice, whether that he witholde the glebe landes or tithes pertayning to the ≈øame, or any parte thereof, or v≈øeth any ≈øimonicall pactes in the be≈øtowinge of
his ≈øayd benefice, and whether he or any in hys name, hath in ye tyme of the vacation of ye church, taken the fruits and profits thereof, and by what authoritie.

Item, whether ye know any Par≈øon or Vicar, that ≈øel their benefice to meare lay men, ab≈øenting them ≈øelues from the ≈øame, to ye defacing of their callinge, decay of ho≈øpitalitie, contempt of the lawes, neglecting of their duties, bothe towards God, and the Queenes maie≈øtie, and euill example of the church of God.
Item, whether your church be vacant, & how long it hath ben ≈øo, and what is the cau≈øe therof.

Item, whether you know, any maintainers of foren power, letters or hinderers of Gods holy word, and ≈ølaunderers of the Preachers or of the mini≈øtery or publike prayer, or that defend or hold any opinions again≈øte them or any of them, who they are expre≈ø≈øing their names, and what was theyr communication.
Item, whether ye know any ≈øpiritual Iudge or his officers, that neglect truely with ≈øinceritie to myni≈øter Iu≈øtice, according to the lawes eccle≈øia≈øticall, indifferently to euery party.

Item, whether they be diligent, and vigilant to enquire of ≈øuch as be noted and commonly famed & ≈øu≈øpected of any notorius crime, as of Adultery, fornication, backbiting, dronkenne≈ø≈øe, & ≈øuch like, and whether they be carefull to correcte ≈øuch offenders, and circum≈øpect with charitie to refourme
≈ømaller faultes.

Item, whether they v≈øe to permitte for ≈øuÃÑmes of money the penaunce of ≈øuche as are notorious offeÃÑders, not caring for ye euil example, & encoragement of others, to commit ye lyke offences, & therby ≈øuffer the ≈øinners to ≈øleepe in theyr ≈øinnes.

Item, whether you know any Parentes, may≈øters, may≈øtre≈ø≈øe, or dames, who doe not ≈øee theyr children or youth taught the Cathechi≈øme, or that do not ≈øeÃÑd their ≈øayd childreÃÑ or youth diligeÃÑtly to ye church to be in≈øtructed therin, & who they are.
Item, whether the Regi≈øter booke of Chri≈øtnings, mariages, and buryings, be well kept, and the names entred accordinge to the Queene hir maie≈øties Iniunctions.

Item, whether there be any Inne kepers, Tauernes, or Ale hou≈øe kepers, that maintaine eating and drinkinge in them vppon any ≈øonday or holiday in the time of preaching or common praier, or if there be any faires or common markets, falling on tho≈øe days, whether they open or make any ≈øhew of their wares before Morning prayer be ended.

Item, whether ye knowe any Bla≈øphemers of the name of God, abu≈øers of his holy word or ≈øacrameÃÑts, adulterers, fornicatours, bawds, & maintayners of them, any ≈øu≈øpect of Ince≈øt, any dronkerdes, ribaldes, or v≈øers of vn≈øomely or filthy talk, common ≈ølaunderers of their neighbours, or ≈øowers of di≈øcord betwene party and party.

Item, whether ye knowe any that mini≈øter any dead mens goods without authoritie, or any executours that haue not fulfilled the te≈øtatours wyll. And whether your Ho≈øpitalls be v≈øed according to the foundation thereof. And whether they receue any other then the poore.

Item, whether ye know any ≈øcholemai≈øter or in≈øtructour of youth that teach, not being lawefully lycen≈øed thereto, vnder the Bi≈øhops Seale. Or any Phi≈øition or ≈øurgeon, that practy≈øe their artes, being not lawfully authori≈øed.

Item, whether your ≈øcholemai≈øters or in≈øtructors of youth, be of ≈øounde religion, and haue taken the Othe to the Queenes maie≈øtie, and doe bring vp his ≈øayde youth, in the feare of GOD, with humilitie, obedience and good maners, to reuerence and geue place to their elders and betters, and doe teach them godly ≈øentences of the Scripture.
Item, whether ye know any that v≈øe any ≈øorcerie, Inchauntments, Magika, Necromancie, Incantations, or Witchcrafte, or that be ≈øu≈øpected of the ≈øame.

Item, whether any of your pari≈øh haue maryed within the degrees of Affinitie, or Con≈øanguinitie, contrary to the lawes, and a ceetayne Table for that purpo≈øe, la≈øte ≈øet foorth by the mo≈øte Reuerend Father, Mathevv, Archby≈øhop of Canterburye, or whether there be any that hath two wiues, or woman that hath two Hu≈øbandes, any maryed
where a precontract was to an other, any deuor≈øed, or otherwi≈øe ≈øeperated that maryed againe, any that haue made priuie or ≈øecret contracts, or haue maryed without a≈øking the banes not being thereunto lawfully lycen≈øed.
Imprinted at London by Iohn VValley. Aprilis. 15.
